author: {'steamid': '76561198205895069', 'num_games_owned': 785, 'num_reviews': 306, 'playtime_forever': 1133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1133, 'last_played': 1586659931}
review:
Impecable juego de Golder Glitch que se podría definir como "Shakesperare + El Día de la Marmota/Hechizo de Tiempo". La progresión está muy llevada y se va notando como en cada ciclo vamos mejorando nuestro manejo de la situación y lo que aprendimos de las iteraciones anteriores. La verdad es increíble como el juego logra engancharte (en mi caso casi 20hs) en una secuencia de 4 días que se repite continuamente sin hacerlo aburrido.
Como recomendación a alguien lo está por empezar o recién lo empezó les aseguro que el juego arranca realmente una vez que se activa el sistema de ciclos (loop). Hasta ese momento nos va a parecer que no podemos hacer mucho o no entendemos la historia.
La verdad este juego me hizo tener ganas de leer la obra real (o por lo menos ver alguna adaptación al cine/tv!).
También como alguna especie de crítica tengo que comentar que para obtener todos los finales tuve que buscar algunos hints ya que habiendo activado todas las frases que podemos decir es difícil mantener en la mente todas las variables distintas que manejamos para producir algunos resultados.
Lo otro que no está tan bueno es que habiendo elegido un final el juego directamente borra el save con lo cual habría que rejugarlo por completo 12 veces más para ver todos los finales (esto lo solucioné copiando el save en el momento en el que los 13 finales estaba desbloqueados, ejecutando uno y al final volviendo a copiar el save). En las discusiones de Steam se pueden encontrar las locaciones de los save games.
En definitiva me pareció un juego super original y de lo mejor que jugué hasta ahora en el año.

Puntaje final: 9.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198274299372', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2887, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2207, 'last_played': 1662354403}
review:
This game is, without a doubt, one of my absolute favorites I've ever played. The characters are remarkably well-written, the time period was researched thoroughly, and the themes of the game were beautiful. 

Two conversations really struck me throughout this game. One was when two characters discuss the pain of unrequited love, especially in the context of loving someone of your same gender. It's so rare to see fully developed, well-rounded LGBT+ characters in video games, and it's even rarer to see this kind of solidarity so beautifully expressed. Not ashamed to admit I cried the first time I saw that conversation. The second was when two characters of color discuss making space for themselves in a world that doesn't want to allow them that space. It struck me as deeply authentic and emotionally honest, and again, a kind of solidarity and love that isn't often represented in video games.

I also love how the writers updated Shakespeare's language while still keeping the overall message intact. That can be hard to do, and as an English teacher, I'm genuinely impressed. I've been a fan of Katie Chironis for a while now (I'm a huge Nancy Drew fan!), so I was thrilled to see her name in the credits!

Please do yourself a favor and get this game. You'll love it!

review:
Really interesting "social mystery" game. Eavesdrop, rumormonger, whisper, and manipulate. I have played three "rounds" of the game and have had WILDLY different experiences each time (and I've not yet solved it). It's very reactive and rewards creativity.

I think what elevates this game to great is that it's a puzzle box but it has a lot of heart and compassion. It's well-written with an eye towards kindness and inclusion. I won't explain how, but just, the game is a pretty good ally if you know what I mean.

edit: Finished the game. Without getting into spoiler territory, this is a much bigger game than I realized. It all takes place in Elsinore (well... mostly) but there are sooo maaannnyyy outcomes. Fortunately, the journal and a late-game mechanic make it easy and fun to keep track of what you've tried and what else you can try. 

There's also a secret ending that I didn't have the heart to do myself.

A lot of love and care and detail went into this beautiful game and I think it will go down as a classic.

review: Elsinore adds depth to Shakespeare's "Hamlet" through the heroine, Ophelia. Ophelia's character is kind, thoughtful, and inquisitive. You want her to succeed in saving her and her friends from meeting grisly ends in the "Groundhog Day" time loop she is forced to repeat. With each three day loop, you learn more about her world and use your knowledge to manipulate it in your attempts to save the residents of Elsinore castle and discover why you are stuck in time. The gameplay is intuitive. You learn the ropes quickly! And, most importantly, I appreciate how inclusive this game is. Ophelia and the other characters are of rich, diverse perspectives and cultural backgrounds. Each character has a unique and interesting story that Ophelia may engage in. This is a beautiful game, easy to play, and fun!

review:
This game isn't bad.  It's even somewhat good.  By it's nature, it's extremely repetitive, but the developers have some clever ways of alleviating that and mixing things up.  And it provides hints without pointing the way directly.

It's just that the game is extremely frustrating to play, and I feel like there's not a lot of payoff for that.  People are really hard to keep alive, and the game is actually designed to make a completely "good" ending impossible, which on the one hand is clever, but also makes your final victory feel... unrewarding?  

I mean, the person you're playing literally considers her life hell.  The hell you're playing through.  Again and again.  It just seems like more frustration than it's worth.

A final note--whether it swings you one way or another, the developers of Elsinore went to great pains to feature a diverse cast of characters (almost implausibly diverse, but whatever, it's a game about time-traveling magic books) and a fair amount of social commentary.  If that annoys you, it's kept more or less low-key, but there's more than a few sequences that are clearly there more for social consciousness than anything related to the story.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995603429', 'num_games_owned': 235, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 597, 'last_played': 1650542364}
review:
A unique and enticing take on Shakespeare's Hamlet! Elsinore is essentially a time looping point and click game. You play as Ophelia, converse with the other actors in the play, witness events, and gather information. You can then use this information to try to influence the outcome of the play, changing the story as you go along. Whilst there is a strong element of repetition, this is mitigated as you can click through conversations fairly quickly, and fast forward through time. This unique game mechanics really works, keeps you hooked, and leaves you yearning to explore more and more of the timeline, with a multitude of different ways events can play out.

In addition, the music is great, and helps bringing about a truly Shakespearean atmosphere. The graphics are modest but functional. The only thing I wish is that the game would be fully voice acted.

All in all, Elsinore represents for me a really great and unique vision towards game design. The way the story evolves across each loop is so cleverly executed, and there is so much choice to ensure that every loop can have its own unique feel and touch. The quality of the conversations is beyond question: it really feels like Shakespeare, and that just never gets old.

Highly recommended if you enjoy a highly cultured and sophisticated gaming experience!

author: {'steamid': '76561198220519669', 'num_games_owned': 3214, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 733, 'last_played': 1580247330}
review:
I decided to wait until achieving the hardest-to-earn ending before writing this review. I regret not taking a screenshot for posterity, especially since I would now need to play another twelve or so hours to get another chance; in contrast to all the time loops you go through while exploring this take on Shakespeare's Hamlet, they really want you to feel like your choice of ending is both meaningful and irreversible, to the point that you've gotta start from scratch if you want to play again. But there's already a screenshot of it somewhere in the Community section, as well as a Youtube video of all the ending narrations, so that alleviated some of the bitterness...even if such flippancy about the cast's fate is more in-line with a villainous perspective.

Anyways! Elsinore is a fascinating experience. It ran mostly fine on my i3 core laptop, though for a couple of cinematic moments, the store page's suggested minimum of i5 would be preferred. The cast of characters are fascinating reinterpretations of their classic portrayals, with even the traitorous Claudius having some sympathetic moments. The gameplay, focusing more on conversation and manipulation than the item-gathering and combining of similar adventure titles, was mostly entertaining. There was decent difficulty in figuring out how different people react to the same rumor, though some reactions just make your other efforts seem wasted, and a myriad of developments that you could see play out as well as directly get involved in.

All in all, I would call this an experience worth sharing, even for those that aren't familiar with classic literature.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005888674', 'num_games_owned': 831, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1579453553}
review:
A triumph of interactive fiction, metafiction, and the looping-tragedy narrative. Elsinore takes a story everyone knows and turns in into a intricate puzzle box of characters, plots, and twists equal to some of my favorite adventure, role-playing and visual novel games.

It balances between adventure-game style puzzle solving and a more expressive style of role-playing and connecting with the characters in ways you don't often see in adventure games - a style similar to an otome game (but only partially). It's a unique combination rarely seen as it puts a hefty burden on both content and structure to remain cogent. Ultimately a game like this lives or dies by its writing, and in this case it lives (and lives, and lives, and lives again).

Overall the writing tends towards making bold and striking choices - no mean feat for an adaptation of a legendary part of the English canon. Just when you think you've gotten your head around one aspect, it throws you for another loop (pun perhaps intended). Yet for a narrative focused game, the degree to which it places the player's attitudes and thoughts in a place of pride is a feat of interactive artistry. Compared to a field that sometimes punts on "narrative mechanics" and reduces it to a systemic set of meters, it's elating to see a game that treats the communication of concrete information and gossip as the mechanics of narrative gameplay. It's more like what you would find in a story-focused tabletop role-playing game, or a theater-style live action role-playing game, or a singular work like Sleep No More than in your average indie adventure game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025434003', 'num_games_owned': 892, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 985, 'last_played': 1579223588}
review:
[b][i]Ophelia s'apprête à vivre une terrible semaine. Piégée dans une boucle temporelle, elle aura l'occasion de voir les personnes qu'elle pensait connaître s'entre-tuer et faire surgir les pires facettes de leur humanité. Existe-t-il une fin positive ? Ou est-elle condamnée à une éternelle boucle de cauchemar ?[/i][/b]

[h1]Theatro Mundi[/h1]

Elsinore est le nom d'une ville Danoise qui est le cadre supposé de "Hamlet", la fameuse pièce de Shakespeare dans laquelle se place notre histoire. Cependant, nul besoin de connaître Hamlet pour jouer à Elsinore, le jeu explique très bien ce qu'il faut savoir et le but n'est de toutes manières pas de reproduire exactement le déroulement de la pièce, on ne joue d'ailleurs pas le héro éponyme mais Ophelia, un personnage secondaire, ancienne compagne d'Hamlet qui finit noyé. Votre première partie se finira donc de manière plutôt abrupte.

[h1]Une semaine sans fin[/h1]

Voilà donc que votre personnage se réveille dans son lit, pleinement consciente que son père se fera tuer de la main d'Hamlet et qu'elle mourra peu de temps après de la main d'une personne masquée. Comme on le sait, le savoir est sans doutes la plus puissante des armes, c'est vrai pour vous, mais aussi pour tous les autres protagonistes. Découvrez l'identité de l'assassin et il vous sera aisé de le faire arrêter. Apprenez les secrets d'une personne et il sera aisé de vous la mettre dans la poche. Vous avez l'éternité pour comprendre chaque rouage de cette semaine.

[h1]Au bord de la folie[/h1]

Bien sûr, il ne suffit pas de lâcher des informations au hasard pour obtenir des résultats. Personne ne vous croira si vous leur dites que vous être coincé dans une boucle temporelle, le simple fait de votre assassinat sera difficile à croire, et comment pourriez vous annoncer l'attaque imminente sur la ville sans qu'on vous prenne pour une folle ? Il vous faudra aussi collecter des preuves, chercher des indices, enquêter et suivre des pistes, manipuler et intriguer. Quant on a l'éternité devant soi, on apprend à être patient.

[h1]Au son du luth[/h1]

Elsinore est accompagné d'une musique parfaitement cadrée dans le thème. Adam Grubman est peu connu sur PC, mais est un compositeur expérimenté travaillant beaucoup pour différents médias. La musique colle si bien au thème qu'elle semble parfois se fondre au jeu, on en oublie qu'elle existe jusqu'à ce qu'elle change, donnant une nouvelle tonalité au jeu, appuyant les moments graves sans pousser à l'excès dans une émotion.

[h1]Comme une peinture[/h1]

Du côté graphique, Elsinore possède un joli style haut en couleur, évoquant quelque peu la peinture, alternant quelques détails précis dans des décors et quelques éléments plus grossiers, simplement évoqués du pinceau. Les dialogues sont accompagnés d'un portrait de l'interlocuteur qui montre avec plus de précision les expressions des personnages que ne le laisseraient voir les modèles 3D.

[h1]Des bases solides[/h1]

Le jeu est stable et les quelques bugs qui peuvent être rencontrés durant une partie ne bloquent pas la progression, beaucoup sont même plutôt rigolo, tel que des personnes assises dans l'air ou des erreurs de Pathfiding. Bien qu'Elsinore soit un projet de passion, créé sur le temps libre d'une petite équipe, les créateurs sont des professionnels expérimentés du milieu informatique, composé d'ingénieurs en IA et d'employés à plein temps dans des studios de renom. En revanche, Elsinore n'existe qu'en anglais et même si le jeu ne reprend heureusement pas l'archaïsme de la langue de Shakespeare, il faudra tout de même un niveau correcte pour pouvoir suivre.

[h1]Contrôler l'information[/h1]

Concrètement, Elsinore est basé sur le contrôle de l'information. Le joueur possède une sorte de journal de quête qui donne des indices sur les possibilités à étudier. Il existe une douzaine de personnages avec lesquels on peut évoquer une liste de sujet qui s'étend au fur et à mesure qu'on apprend des choses. Ce qui est intéressant, c'est que certains de ces sujets permettent de partager une information avec quelqu'un ou de changer ce qu'il pense. Le jeu nous signale, à l'aide d'une boîte de texte d'une manière qui semble grossière et plutôt bizarre au début, tel que "Quelqu'un pense désormais Quelque chose" et que "Tel évènement arrivera dans le futur si possible", ce qui s'affichera alors sur l'agenda du joueur.

[h1]La reine et ses pions[/h1]

Chaque personnage est donc entièrement prévisible puisqu'il reproduira à priori les mêmes actions lors de chaque partie, qu'on pourra vérifier sur l'agenda. Mais la force d'Elsinore, c'est que certaines informations vont radicalement changer ce que les personnages font. Quelques paroles suffisent à donner la mort ou à protéger des vies. Plus le jeu avance, plus nos options sont connues et plus on se sent puissant. Pour autant, il nous est toujours impossible de briser la boucle.

[h1]Contempler l'abîme[/h1]

On finit peu à peu par perdre pied, par ne plus voir les autres que comme des leviers qui peuvent être manipuler. On se voit appuyer sur des boutons, expérimenter avec des vies humaines, mais dans quel but ? Existe-t-il seulement une conclusion à cette histoire ? Quel prix êtes-vous prêt à payer pour arriver à vos fins ? Vous possédez un grand pouvoir, mais personne pour vous mettre face à vos responsabilités. Conserverez vous votre raison ou deviendrez-vous un monstre ?

author: {'steamid': '76561198274438291', 'num_games_owned': 303, 'num_reviews': 158, 'playtime_forever': 2583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 956, 'last_played': 1590882239}
review:
First off, I adore Hamlet, and I'd say the creators did an excellent job of fleshing out the characters, filling in gaps in the narrative, creating backstories, and tucking away plenty of fun Easter eggs. The graphics and controls are smooth and pleasant, and for the most part, this game is a joy to play. Well done.
Unfortunately, the game also feels like a preachy comment on modern social and political issues, and that sharply pulls focus away from the story of Ophelia/Hamlet, the story we're all here to enjoy. Much of the artistic license has absolutely no purpose other than to serve as the creators' soapbox: A handful of characters were changed to mixed race, a black character was pulled in from another play, some of the male characters were changed to women, one of the characters is a lesbian, another is a gay man, one straight character decides to sexually experiment with a character of the same sex, and another character is nonbinary and transgender. I swear I'm not joking or exaggerating. Add to this the out of place conversations about racial and gender inequality and transgenderism, and you've got a disappointing game that had SO much potential. I played this game because I love Hamlet, not because I wanted to be lectured and patronized. I'm not against their views or opinions, but I'm very much against awkwardly shoehorning them into Hamlet. It's all extremely out of place.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025521262', 'num_games_owned': 600, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 967, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 967, 'last_played': 1578809339}
review:
They're not kidding when they tell you it feels like you've been doing this for a century.

[i]Elsinore[/i] is a pretty spectacular time-loop organization game based on Shakespeare's classic tragedy [i]Hamlet[/i]. And um... word to the wise, but it really does make you feel like garbage. Which is good, I think. If I was groundhogging the deaths of everyone I loved over and over I'd feel terrible, and [i]Elsinore[/i] captures that slow climb to desperation as you relive the same four days over and over again trying to math together how to get to a reality that's [i]maybe[/i] better than the last one you stumbled into by killing the Queen accidentally and then sleeping with her widower.

It's a game that explores a lot of ugly emotions: cruelty, hatred, boredom. Which I like actually, I like a lot, and feel that gaming needs more of if it really wants to call itself an art form. Between the ugliness and the overall emotional difficulty of the story, there lies a lot of humor, lost loves, resolute wills, tenderness, humanity. And of course there's a #GenocideRoute. Which to me is kind of high school nihilism, but I digress.

I'm really impressed. I think it's a shame that this game seems to not have received much visibility, because as a work of design, it's staggering how neatly woven all of the ripple effects are. How every little thing you do touches the world around you and yet ultimately affects nothing, furthering the feeling of being trapped. As a work of narrative, it's amazing how you get to understand all the characters so well that you know all their motivations and believe that yes, this is an inevitability for this character, whether you're getting stabbed by them or sending them to get executed.

It is kinda buggy, which given the amount of everything that's going on, I can understand. Lots of characters clip into one another when scenes overlap, triggering too many things to happen simultaneously sometimes skips you ahead on dialogue. Scenes get interrupted by scenes with more priority. Nothing major, nothing crashing.

It does have a real "indie" feel, with limited voice acting, character models being quite simple and limited in poses, the world, of course, is small in scale. I'm not against those things, but I know some people have grand expectations that everything be [i]Outer Wilds[/i] or something of the sort.

Otherwise I have little criticism. The game contains LGBTQ+ stories, which I love. Takes the ideas of race and class seriously in its portrayal of the world. Discusses and makes visceral its very nature, the nature of the game, and if choice is possible within a game.

And that I guess is the criticism that is not mine, but should be addressed? Choosing an ending deletes your save. There are 13 endings. None of them completely happy, as befitting a tragedy. The philosophy the game holds is that there is no real choice in a world where everything is possible and you can always turn back time to change things. A problem I have held for a long time with games where supposedly "choices matter." It upsets people, but I think the game is all the better for holding true to it. You get your chance to experience a story again and again until you feel numb to the idea that you have any control at all, and then you get to make a single true choice that ends it. That's pretty powerful.

EDIT: Sadly, it appears the devs have decided to to change the way the ending works to allow viewing multiple endings. While I wish they stuck to their guns, I respect their right to change their game and still endorse it wholeheartedly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198287272755', 'num_games_owned': 261, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 3129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1821, 'last_played': 1609483843}
review:
[b]I checked "received product for free" even though I wasn't necessarily given the game code/some sort of endorsement thing. I managed to get Winter Sale 2019 Discount Coupon, and used it on this game, so I basically spent less than 1 dollar for this game, which might still cause me to view this game slightly favorably.[/b]

[h1]A work of art, best experienced as intended... [b]but many regret how it's intended to be experienced.[/b][/h1]

The review is shorter than what I want to tell to potential new players(what I want to tell is part of the final Con actually), so here goes, my short (+)pros and (-)cons review:

(+)[b]Story[/b]= main selling point. Of course, heavily inspired by Hamlet, and I can't speak much about how well they adapted and modified it, but I like the story and it's possibilities.
(+)[b]Voice Acting[/b]= Not fully-voiced lines, but not just sighs/sound effects, although [i]basically just sighs and sound effects[/i], it voices like 1 or 2 words per sentence spoken by the characters in-game. Seeing as it's an Indie game, I think the devs have done their part and it's better than no voice acting at all.
(+)[b]Music[/b]= fitting. not spectacularly distinct.

(-)[b]slightly tedious[/b]. Basically, follow around characters, or click the map when you see a room in blue(which signifies an event/conversation is happening), learn things, talk about things to people and further investigate and try possibilities, learn from your past, die, repeat. this alone is not enough to make me dislike it. But the fact that the Timeline shows possible events only based on what we currently learn this loop makes no sense. A good example is the "missing lute" lead in-game. If you talk to 2 NPCs about "missing lute", they meet up in the castle ground. If you hear their convo, you then learn they'll go to the walls. Hear their convo, learn they'll go to the ponds and find the lute. However, the next loop/life, after talking to them about the missing lute, you only predict the 1st possible meetup on your timeline, as if you forget the things that'll happen next. BUT, information/leads, you remember/know between loops. Makes no goddamn sense to me. Atleast all things that are put in motion still happen even when you don't attend them.
(-)[b]Game could be more transparent[/b] with it's "what-leads-to-what". Lots of things to keep track of. If the game doesn't really provide "what leads to what", only relying on the player to remember things that happened in past loops, atleast I think the game should give us an in-game-notebook to type out any things we want to tell ourselves to remember in future loops. It's annoying to do wrong things over and over again because we forgot what we should and shouldn't do, example, if mentioning something causes someone to kill themselves, on the next loop, the game should warn us before we click on it.
(-)[b]Ending[/b]. Not the ending plot-wise, but how the game treats endings. Minor spoiler but you will get a magical book which contains 11 possible endings. Actually, there's 2 more secret-ish endings. However, to pick an ending, that ending must happen in a previous loop. When you do pick an ending, the thing you will get that you haven't seen before is a 5-10 minute narration/video, all either poetic, beautiful or tragic. [b]then the game DELETES YOUR SAVE FILE. not only that, YOU LOSE ALL YOUR LEADS. not only that, PLAY THROUGH THE PROLOGUE AGAIN. also, TUTORIAL TIPS. literal full on delete.[/b] This is where it has become a topic of issue with most players. I understand, by picking "cement your fate" on an ending, the developer intends for us to never replay the game, due to the fact you probably spent 10-20 hours on your first playthrough and wouldn't want to spend 10x10 more hours on the game. but we, gamers who like to achieve, complete, and be curious about other possibilities, want to see all endings. Well, this is what I want to say to potential new players. YOU DON'T need to see all 10 endings out of 11. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LP4IczoHEJk
there, 13 endings, [b][h1]you would not lose anything by watching that video,[u]provided that you HAVE unlocked the ending in your book[/u][/h1][/b]. However, the last 2 endings are [b]best experienced on your own, since there are gameplay parts and in-game dialogue critical to those secret endings.[/b]

Further more, in my quest to see these "secret endings" and how to obtain them, I stumbled upon a steam thread https://steamcommunity.com/app/512890/discussions/0/1606022547904296852/ where someone attempts a speedrun of Elsinore.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gl2H5gitZ_M

Now, the important thing is this. [b] you can obtain the book in less than 1 hour from a blank slate [/b]. So don't be too discouraged to see the 2 secret endings as I earlier was.

on the second video's description, there is a link to Pastebin, a site for notes basically, which provides the rundown on what to do and when, although slightly confusing. https://pastebin.com/LRGKawFZ Alternatively, just watch the speedrun and do what they do. 

Final thoughts: Good game. I wish someone told me what I'm telling you now about the endings.
[b][u][h1]Update 19 May 2020[/h1][/u][/b]: they updated the game which apparently changes how endings work. It was not explained in post and idk what it entails, but there's a chance that endings are now better.

review: Elsinore is perfectly playable even if you've never read or watched Hamlet, but the game really does feel laser-targeted to Shakespeare nerds who want to spend a handful of hours looping through timelines from Ophelia's perspective and seeing how far off the rails they can drag the play's plot. In some loops, Hamlet himself becomes basically a bit player as you devote your days to teasing out seemingly minor characters' important stories so that you can bring your new knowledge to bear on subsequent timelines. The game also takes time to explore issues of gender, race, and sexuality in ways that add new life to the play. I had a great time trying to sort out everyone's motivations, nudge characters toward action with bits of gossip, and manipulate the body count to get to an acceptable ending for my long-suffering protagonist. A+ groundhog day despair simulator, 100% recommended.

review:
Elsinore has nearly no filler; almost everything serves towards one of the many endings. This is good and bad, I cant decide. More fluff might provide more character and give characters life between their scenes, many tend to stand in their “spot,” but I also appreciate how economic the game is. Nothing ever gets in the way of the plot. Most leads go down one of the story paths and the few red herrings are fun mini stories. Everything about the game is efficient. You can fast forward time and zip around with the mini map completing complex stories in minutes. After understanding the clockwork movements of its players you are like a god of the castle.
The paths are all fun and the “final” ending is satisfyingly complicated. Another great time loop game!

review:
I found Elsinore after bouncing pretty hard off of one of the classic LucasArts adventure games -- I enjoy the genre, but I am entirely over walking around clicking on arbitrary inventory items to try to progress in a game.

Elsinore resembles an adventure game, but it is almost entirely free of inventory puzzles. (And in general the puzzles are not as hard as they are in the average text adventure.) It also resembles choose-your-own-adventure games to an extent, but most of the choices you make are implicit, i.e. you walk around and do things, instead of explicit stop-the-world decision prompts. And the time loop game mechanic means that most decisions are not irrevocable: you can always choose differently on your next run.

Overall there were just enough game/puzzle elements to be satisfying, but not so many as to be frustrating or to take away the focus from the story and the writing, which are both fantastic. This game is creative, thoughtful, and fun, and I'm so glad I found it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038625342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 1380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1038, 'last_played': 1571101056}
review:
So…Elsinore…it’s a masterpiece.  This game is so drastically better than the bulk of adventure games I’ve played on steam that it’s just quite frankly embarrassing.  I do have a degree in literature with a focus on Shakespeare…so I might be a tad biased.  The game literally feels like it was made for me. The only negatives I can even say about the game are that it’s unfortunate it’s not fully voice acted and it’s a shame the soundtrack isn’t bigger.  For a game where you are reliving day after day having a more robust soundtrack is pretty important.  However, those are minor issues in an otherwise incredible game.

So many games say your decisions matter…those games are a joke compared to Elsinore.  Every line of dialogue you spout has ripple affects that change the course of events in the game.  The idea that you are stuck in a time loop and hence constantly reliving what is happening was genius.  Having the ability to see how those ripples unfold and then going back and trying again was a joy for me.  I assumed that’s what the “Sexy Brutale” was going to be.  A murder mystery where you can use time travel to change the course of events…that was a lie.  That game is just a linear puzzle game with an extremely weak story.  Elsinore is the game I thought “Sexy Brutale” was going to be.  

Going around spying on people and finding out what type of person they truly are has a very detective feeling to it.  I found myself changing events just so I could spy on different people interacting.  I wish this game was a murder mystery with the exact same premise.  That would probably be my ideal.  Everyone knows Hamlet so it’s not really a “mystery,” but there are enough twists here that this game does border on being a mystery/detective game.  The real fun in the game comes from the simple fact that everyone knows Hamlet and probably at one time or another has thought, hey maybe if only someone had said something to Hamlet the play would not have ended in a bloodbath.  This is your chance to do so and try all sorts of ridiculous machinations.  It’s just so perfect.

Anyone who knows anything about Shakespeare can tell how much craft and care went into this game.  The writing in this game is just superb.  These developers have really outdone themselves.  I just paid $50 for Greedfall…a game with horrendous writing and a game where basically no decisions matter.  Elsinore is a bargain at $20 for the quality of writing in this game.  Sure wish these people worked on Greedfall, that might have actually been a good game if they had.  I am so excited to see what this dev team does next.  They have shown they have the writing skills that are worlds beyond the bulk of most videogames.

[spoiler] My biggest issue in the game for me is simply their seems to be no way to make Laertes King married to Brit…it’s confusing because they have dialogue that leads me to believe they will…but I never saw such an ending.  I also hated Hamlet…I never felt he should be King…he’s a crazy person, who had just an idiotic plan.  I wanted an ending where I could Kill Hamlet and either have Claudius and Gerturde happy or at least Laertes and Brit together.  I certainly didn’t want Ophelia marrying Hamelt, he’s nuts…which sure comes across in his ending since he banishes the rest of your family if you marry him.  I also do wish there was a way to turn the play from a tragedy into a comedy by having everyone happy and married off at the end…sadly there is not. Again…this is a minor concern, I'll settle for the Guilda ending huzzah! [/spoiler]

This game really gets at the idea that so many of Shakespeare’s tragedies are only tragedies because of one person’s critical flaw or misstep and all of his comedies are one misstep away from being a tragedy.  Everyone who has any love of adventure games or Shakespeare should be playing this game #Worth Any Price.

review:
Let me get the criticism out of the way first--if you're going to play this game, you're going to need some suspension of disbelief, and I don't mean from the premise: you're going to have to accept that Ophelia can stand plain in the middle of the room yet nobody can see her, you're going to have to accept that people are extremely gullible and will believe rumors about someone's death even when that someone is standing next to them, and you're going to have to accept that some permutations of events are going to result in people acting illogically based on the full picture. 

All that, however, is just a matter of minor polish, because you can easily imagine the scenarios in which those were intended to occur. What a game like this lives and dies by is its writing, and in that, the game excels. As you play, it becomes very clear that the writers have an unparalleled love for Shakespeare, and that they've honored the Bard's work in the best way they could, short of using iambic pentameter themselves. Anyone who still remembers Hamlet will note a number of interesting twists they've put on the classic play, and will be pleasantly surprised by how progressive the story is, given the era it originates from. All these changes work in concert to make every character much more dimensioned than their counterparts in the original text, and somehow, you leave this game feeling like you know the cast of Hamlet better than you ever did before playing it.

review:
Elsinore is an incredible game. Starting with the concept of Ophelia time-looping through Hamlet in order to get a better ending, and somehow managing to be even better than that original concept. It was one of the most enjoyable things I have ever played.
The only thing I could think of that would benefit it is a text skip button (several dialogues can be skipped and most long ones don't need to be repeated, but there are a handful of exceptions). Absolutely worth picking up.
Also, I just picked up the soundtrack on Bandcamp, and it is incredible. Also worth listening to.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040603623', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1161, 'last_played': 1579494555}
review:
In Elsinore, you play as Ophelia who is trapped in a time loop, reliving the same four days again and again. Ophelia has the power to change the course of events by investigating and sharing what she’s learned with others. It’s a highly interesting and thought provoking game. I would highly recommend it if you like mystery games and/or visual novels. It isn’t without its problems. I took a bit of an issue with some of the controls, the saving, and the darkness of the game.

Pros:
- Characters are extremely deep and complex. Most behave in a way that totally makes sense based on their personalities and experiences. And you even continue to learn more about their personalities and pasts as the game went on.
- So many variations in the loops! It was amazing how effort went into this game to make each loop feel so different and fresh!
- Don’t need to have seen Hamlet to understand what’s going on. It also has a lot of new stuff for long-time fans as well.
- Great story with well executed twists and turns.
- Cats and dogs you can pet
- Great music and environments
- Easy to use GUI and simple controls
- For each step in the story there are usually multiple intuitive ways that let you get there. I never felt like I knew something Ophelia didn’t. When I tried to solve the problem using dialogue options given to me by the game in an interesting way, the game let me.
- Was thought provoking enough to be challenging but intuitive enough to not be frustrating. I probably didn’t need to use a guide.
- Diverse characters! POC characters and queer characters! This isn’t just an aesthetic choice either, the issues the characters face based on their backgrounds and identities is a major focus in the game. I love a strong female lead, especially a WOC!

Cons:
- No dialogue skipping means a lot of rapidly clicking or punching the spacebar over and over again to get through dialogue you’ve seen before. Setting text speed to instant is helpful but doesn’t entirely eliminate this issue.
- Can lose dialogue options in the sea of dialogue options sometimes and spent minutes searching for what you need.
- Save files are wiped when you choose and ending (unless you hunt around on your computer and back it up). I think this was an interesting artistic choice to make your choice seem final, but in reality it didn’t work so well. In real life people don’t choose an ending, we continue to make choices until death. There were some endings where I felt like I got roped with an ending I didn’t really expect and wanted to go back and see the others had in store.
- I feel like there’s a lot of options missing from the game which would make it nicer but ruin the theme it’s trying to present. I wished I could quote Hamlet’s soliloquies back at him. I wish there was more I could do to warn and convince others of what was happening, but  that would make the theme of the tragedy not work as well, and perhaps make the bad things too easy to avert.

I really enjoyed the beginning and middle of the game, but I got disillusioned at the end with just how dark it went. [Spoiler about the nature of the endings ahead, nothing too explicit:] [spoiler]There is no purely “good” or “bad” end. Most are just depressing as hell. I did the one of the darker and morally disturbing endings last which left me a bit shaky and with a rather sour taste in my mouth. Very few ended with hopeful tones. I know the theme of the game is the inevitable tragedy, but it was just such a downer. I didn’t feel like there were lessons to be learned from most of the tragic endings. They were just sad, dark, and sometimes just disturbing. Ophelia felt so lonely without many people to honest to god talk to or believe the nightmare she was trapped in. I’m definitely someone who likes a bit of fluff, so I’m gonna have to sacrifice some reality for joy I think. [/spoiler] 

I definitely recommend this game however! An experience I will never forget. :)

review:
I bought and played this game just days after it was released. I wanted to wait until I finished the game before making a review of it but honestly, I have had decision-anxiety over the ending for so long (plus, I got busy and forgot).  I bought this game because I follow one of the writers on social media and wanted to support her work and was interested in what she was producing- so going into it I had no idea what I would be playing. I've never seen or read Hamlet so the story was completely new to me as well. After playing for 8 hours I watched a YouTube video on Hamlet and the way Elsinore tells its version(s) of the story is so eloquently done! 

The mechanics are all well done. I have to say that I fully utilized the timeline, the fast-forward, the character descriptions, the map, etc. There isn't any waste in what they've supplied for you to use. In a time-loop game the dialogue can easily get obnoxious but this game does a great job of reiterating what needs to be seen again and skipping through (even comically) what doesn't need to be. The "puzzles" you need to solve range in challenge level and even if you don't solve one of the puzzles there's always another puzzle that can get you to the end of the game. 

Which brings me to my next point- the endings. My one issue about this game doesn't even lie with the game itself- its my own decision-anxiety that has rendered me unable to finish it. I absolutely love that you can get to an ending through so many ways but my nature as a completionist and also decision-anxiety has stopped me in making a game ending decision. 

This is a game that you could play multiple times, taking a different approach and receiving a different result every time. I'll definitely just bite the poison tipped sword and choose an ending so I can jump back in and start again! Well done Elsinore team!

author: {'steamid': '76561198052835313', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 719, 'last_played': 1566740497}
review:
Elsinore is a story based on the setting of the play Hamlet. Ophelia relives a set of critical days over and over again, given a chance to change the course of events by learning the secrets of the court. The game it reminds me of most is Majora's Mask without any of the dungeons. The game has a living timeline which in some sense functions as the Bomber's Notebook, but the twists and turns are much more involved. It might be more fair to compare it to certain works of interactive fiction (text adventures) such as Hadean Lands, Varicella, or Lock & Key that similarly focus on solving puzzles through resets.

Fair warning: If you are the sort of person that will take issue with the fact that Ophelia and Laertes are persons of color, this is not the game for you. Some of the content seems anachronistic, but this wasn't a problem for me since this is a game about time-traveling shenanigans.

Not to say I don't have criticisms. A couple issues are minor mechanical gripes that only really started to wear on me at the end, namely that sometimes finding particular conversation topics in a large list is tedious and sometimes I wanted to be able to straight-up skip ahead in time rather than use the given fast-forward feature.

The more substantive issue is an issue with how the game handles endings. Once you want to choose an ending, the game up front lets you know that any ending will delete your save. You thus have to start from square zero (or back up your saves) to see any others in full. Now I get what the devs were going for, but when it comes down to brass tacks it's just gating content off through extraneous tedium. If only one or two endings triggered save deletion as opposed to all of them (and there are a fair number) I'd probably be OK with it.

Overall, however, the game was a unique experience and well worth playing. It ran well considering how ancient my computer is. The visuals and audio do are suitable to set the stage for the writing, which is strong. There is a large amount of narrative content given that this is coming from a small indie team.

review: Elsinore is a unique experience, skillfully adapting Hamlet into a new medium. Following games like Majora’s Mask, Elsinore simulates time-looping schedules and interweaves character-focused stories into a larger, almost epic narrative. There’s even a character that’s a perfect stand-in for Majora’s Mask’s Happy Mask Salesman. However, this is not an action-adventure, but a dialogue-driven, adventure-simulation game.  You get to explore and dive into a surprisingly deep range of possibilities, from various murders to various romances. You get to choose narrative paths and dialogue options, like an adventure game. You also get to experiment with characters bouncing off one another, like you’re playing a game of the Sims. While doing so, you get to experience a fleshed-out world of Hamlet. Characters are adapted, reinterpreted, given expanded backstories, and feel both freshly relatable and believable to the source material. Thematically, the game dwells on the long recent fixation on choice and agency. What’s interesting is how the game emphasizes that there’s no perfect way to play or end. There are many ending outcomes, each a different flavor of bittersweet, and each feel earned and appropriate. The game’s art style is like a living painting, and while the graphics, such as the character models and animation, lack polish, they are serviceable. The music feels appropriate to the mood and setting, but can at times sound repetitive, as the game’s main theme is often reused and replayed. So, without a doubt, Elsinore is a fun, thought-provoking, and moving game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198882449707', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1218, 'last_played': 1565669272}
review:
I'm not much of a gamer, and I only found out about this game because the writer, Katie Chironis, wrote one of my favorite Nancy Drew games, Sea of Darkness. That game had fantastic characters and story, so I had high hopes for Elsinore, and I was not disappointed. It also helps that I'm a Shakespeare buff--it's so fun to get to explore all the "what-ifs" of the play. And despite all the forking paths, added dialogue, and subplots not in the original text, it still feels true to Shakespeare's work. There were also quite a few Easter eggs for the Shakespeare fans.
It's impressive how rich the game is, especially considering the developers did this essentially in their spare time. Every time I thought I'd solved something, some new path would crop up--in a good way! There were so many great side conversations you could discover that weren't necessary to the main plot but were given depth all the same. A lot of these conversations involved issues of gender, race, and sexuality, and the underlying message, of a tragic Shakespearean woman taking control of her own fate, is a powerful one. 
The only downside is one that you would expect from a time loop: it can get tiresome having the same conversations again and again to trigger a certain action in each loop. I wish there could've been some sort of shortcut for these or a way to skip a convo you've previously had. But on the whole, an excellent game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198078145371', 'num_games_owned': 1039, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1292, 'last_played': 1565202459}
review:
[h1]Exactly how a groundhog game should be.... almost[/h1]

First of all let me just say I was HYPED the second I first heard of this game YEARS ago, a groundhog day game based on Hamlet as Ophelia? Awesome! I was in and now that it's finally out I have to say... it's just as good as I had hoped.
The game is fascinating. It takes the timeloop concept and runs as far as it can with it, depending on what you say, when you say and to whom to say it to, you can change the outcome of the tragic story of hamlet. 

The game is HUGE, not in the sense of games like No mans sky or Skyrim in terms of scale as it all mostly takes place in Elsinore which is quite small, but of scope, EVERY character you can meaningly speak to are fully developed characters, everyone with their own philosophies, vices, issues and secrets, It's an exploration of PEOPLE. Not only that, but EVERY character has a schedule you can follow or alter, it feels ALIVE in a way most open world games dream of. You have SO MANY options to change events around i'm pretty sure I still haven't seen all there is to this game. It's what's so great about the timeloop mechanic, you become intimately familiar with each location and person, I can't stress how FANTASTIC such a concept is and you know what? It made me realise that I would love this type of storytelling to be more common.

Naturally because this is also based on the story of Hamlet which I am sure most people were forced to read in school at some point, you know how it goes and you can use this information to your advantage, it rocks. What I also found pretty interesting was combining elements from other Shakespeare stories, which i'll leave for you to discover.

The voice acting is unusual in the sense that it's there but also not there, oh there were voice acters but the dialog uses the Zelda approach of words and sounds to start off each paragraph, I am okay with this, it just felt weird when characters did say full lines. Not really a point against the game, the amount of text must have been notably longer than the book so I don't blame them. But it would've been nice. The character models... aren't amazing but you'll mostly be looking at the great character portraits when they speak so again i'm a-ok with it.

Also yes, Ophelia is a person of color in this game, in fact numerous characters have had their race and even genders changed up and while I'm sure this will annoy some (for stupid reasons), my goodness does it enhance the story in every way. it does something that a lot of "woke" re-imaginings of older things get wrong; THEY ACTUALLY ADDRESS IT, the fact that she is a person of color in Denmark is not only explained but absolutely integral to her character and makes her WAY more interesting, the same applies to all the other characters, explaining their actions and beliefs in ways that make perfect sense and make the story more interesting and a little more fun.

NOW THERE IS ONE THING TO NOTE THAT STOPS ALL THIS FROM BEING DAMN NEAR PERFECT
With a game like this where you have so many options, you naturally have multiple endings, however with ONE, MAJOR, CAVEAT.
When you choose an ending, you lose your save files and you have to start from scratch to see them, which is likely several hours work. Sure you will be warned when certain courses of actions will lead to an end, but it still is rather obnoxious that this is a thing. Which is why I recommend you BACKUP YOUR SAVES if you wanna get the most out of the game. This is the "almost" part of my title and if you keep it in mind I think you will enjoy the game even more.

With that being said, I REALLY liked this game, it made me think at night of how to change things in specific way to reach a specific outcome until you get that "AHA!" moment, anyone interested in a relatively relaxed casual but deep heavily story and character driven based game should give this a go.

review:
I purchased this game at full price and it took me about 12 hours to complete without a walk-through.

Pros

+ Diverse and deep character stories
+ Unusual and fun story mechanism
+ Expressive and wide voice acting
+ Great contrast of comedy and tragedy
+ Shakespeare references abound and really highlight how emo Hamlet is
+ Text appearance can be set to instant
+ Character walking speed not restricted to slow (use the clock)

Neutral

~ Still a little buggy (as of 7 Aug 2019) but nothing game-breaking at all

Cons

- None

This is an excellent game and I fully recommend it to anyone, although not to be played with small children as there's a lot of death, as you expect from a Hamlet-em-up. In terms of how it felt to play, I'd put it with Return Of The Obra Dinn.

review:
Wow.  I got this game because the basic premise was exactly my interests, and I was impressed at first.  It was a really cool, if slightly buggy, game that delivered on the promise of Hamlet meets Groundhog Day.  After about 3 hours, I would have said solid 4/5, highly recommended and very enjoyable.

Then I got into some of the stranger outcomes.  I don't want to say too much for fear of spoilers, but there's a turn in this game.  It begins to delve into itself in a way that I've rarely seen before.  It stops simply executing the premise well and goes far beyond that.  I just got what I can only imagine is the final ending and I'm shook.  I'm disturbed and in awe and sitting here just... thinking.  Incredible ending, not just an interesting take on Shakespeare, but an original look at the Groundhog Day premise as well.  5/5, anyone who enjoys narrative games should play this.  Brilliant.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014107704', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1609, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1468, 'last_played': 1566390489}
review:
I played Elsinore primarily for the groundhog day time travel, I've never been huge on shakespeare and I've still never actually watched all of Hamlet. That said, it didn't diminish my enjoyment of this game. I love almost all of the characters, and the only ones I dislike are the ones I'm meant to, they're all so well-made and fleshed out. There's a surprising amount of representation in this game too, that I would have to say wasn't there in the play. I don't think Rosencrantz and Guildenstern were a couple of lesbian/bi women in the original, somehow. You may have noticed Ophelia is black (she's of mixed heritage) and its actually talked about! There's just this feeling that the game was put together with mindfulness towards making sure people can see themselves in at least part of its cast, and Golden Glitch have accomplished that without making it incongruous with the time period. 

Also its super fun to play and I was intrigued at every turn! I never felt like I was chafing against a lack of options to do what I thought was sensible, the game accommodated my thought process. I'm playing through to find all the endings, but its worth playing even if you only do it once! Also the ending credits song is pretty dope.

review:
Playing this game is like starring as the hero in your very own thriller/horror movie set on Shakespearean castlegrounds. Elsinore is hands down the most thoughtfully crafted, addictive game I've played in a really long time. 
The narrative of being an outcast and of not having power over our own lives were explored in such amazing ways with a number of characters in this game. Given that Ophelia in the original story is a girl who is used crudely by her father Polonius, Hamlet, and the king for their own gain, and goes mad and kills herself, this game asks WHAT IF that wasn't true? It's freakin empowering and entertaining to play this character with the agency she deserves, FINALLY. 
Other observations: 
1. The Story/Writing: You don't have to know Hamlet to enjoy the very compelling story of this game. And the game is welcoming and well written enough to get you familiar with the plots very quickly. Surprisingly, I never got bored. The fast forward button made it so that even though we were stuck in a time loop, it rarely got repetitive. Even then, there was SO MUCH to explore that things were constantly changing to the point that I was constantly on the edge of my seat. The story struck just the right balance between challenging and giving you hints when you need them, in my opinion. 
2. Characters: Again, you don't have to know these classic characters beforehand. But if you do, you can tell the team did their research, plus added a lot of their own twists. The character's point of views were strong and their actions logical. The relationships were deep and interesting. I found myself very emotionally invested in them. 
Diversity of Stories: Although I have played lots of games in my lifetime, it is rare if not unheard of to play as a fully realized WOC protagonist. I was also THRILLED that there were POC and Queer folks in this game. In Shakespeare's world, in gaming, and let's face it: the media, a lot of these voices are excluded or stereotyped to stupid extremes. This game did not do that. More than that, these people, including Ophelia herself, are not in the game to simply exist as faces, but are REAL and COMPLEX HUMAN BEINGS WITH hopes and dreams. I don't have to remind anybody that this type of representation is what we need in this day and age. 
To the creators, of this game, this game truly made me happy. Brava! THANK YOU!!!!!!

review:
this is a Hamlet simulator where you run around a castle, manipulating and tricking people into doing what you want... a lot of the game is about figuring out "what if", and then actually going ahead and doing it -- what if Hamlet tried to kill everyone from the beginning? what if someone else killed Hamlet first? etc.

this game, and Heaven's Vault, are two of the most complicated narrative games ever made, and it's great to live in 2019 to see these games get made and get finished

if you like mystery puzzles and story games, definitely check this out, it's pretty long and makes for a great game to watch / play co-op with -- it's about reading a lot of dialogue, remembering clues, and pursuing theories to see what happens, so it's fun to discuss it with a friend or significant other and helps relieve the burnout that happens with detective games sometimes

and if you don't know anything about Shakespeare, don't worry, it's fine

author: {'steamid': '76561198014849103', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 719, 'last_played': 1564806517}
review:
[i]Elsinore[/i] is the time-looping Hamlet simulator I never knew I wanted. It even has a built-in timeline view where you can see when the consequences of your actions are scheduled to come up (and which events you have made impossible in the current timeline). It's really impressive from a mechanical standpoint.

From a narrative standpoint, it also holds together remarkably well. This game often feels like a sandbox simulation, giving me a lot of freedom in how and when I try to accomplish my goals. Despite that freedom, I've almost never managed to make the game do anything weird or glitchy. The sequence of events flows admirably.

The writing is smooth and life-like. Every character has at least a little bit of backstory to them which can be discovered in a variety of ways. Some artistic liberties and embellishments keep things interesting, and I appreciated them. In a dialogue-driven game based on a Shakespearean play, what could be more important than words, words, words? Fortunately, [i]Elsinore[/i] excels in this department.

The voice acting is a nice touch. Rather than fully voicing all the lines, the characters have short utterances that convey their tone or mood alongside their dialogue text. These do a great job of establishing their personalities. For example, Hamlet's dialogue is surly much of the time, but it's his accompanying grunt of exasperation and his incredulous, "What?!" that firmly expresses just how restless and agitated he is.

The music is beautiful when it shows up, predominantly warm guitar and flute.

The art is an interesting combination of painterly backdrops and 3D models walking around on them. I was especially impressed by the real-time shadows when watching how they crept across the land while I moved time forward. My only complaints here would be that the 3D model animations are a bit cartoonish (they are more akin to pantomime and noticeably reused throughout), and that there are several scenes where Ophelia "hides" in rooms very unconvincingly. But if we can suspend our disbelief about the positioning of characters, and focus on the dialogue instead, this is not too big of a problem.

Overall, this is a well-written, well-made time-loop simulation adventure. I greatly enjoyed trying out many different strategies and watching how my choices played out. These were characters I liked spending time with. I am left wishing for more games with this amount of depth, quality writing, and clever design. Highly recommended to anyone who likes narrative games with immersive, reactive worlds, or who is a fan of time travel fiction in general.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032305892', 'num_games_owned': 67, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1298, 'last_played': 1570081706}
review:
This is a stunning work of interactive narrative. I've never played anything like it: you have an incredibly dense simulation space, with the castle in Hamlet over the course of a time loop, and are free to change it freely - and it responds! It makes sense! On top of that - you never feel directionless. You've got objectives. You've got reasons to explore the different ways things could go.

Not only is it unique, it's effective: between equally amazing writing and soundtrack, you will get thoroughly invested in the lives of these characters and Ophelia's search for a better ending to her story. I honestly can't recommend this highly enough. Even if Hamlet isn't your favourite play (it's not mine), you should play this. 

I wasn't sure anything could beat Heaven's Vault for my pick of 2019. I think this might have. ...Or at least tied. HV is very good, too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083947677', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 5172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2055, 'last_played': 1636084074}
review:
Elsinore is a wonderful game. I'm so glad I backed this one. Hopefully that doesn't spoil this review for you. Elsinore is a time loop game but Bill Murray isn't anywhere to be found. Instead, you are Ophelia and if you remember your Shakespeare, you'll remember she has a rough go of it. Well, the game starts out that way but Ophelia gets to start over and see if things can't turn out a little differently. 

The positives? Great graphics, a fantastic timeline that lets you see upcoming events and plan accordingly. You also can review dialogue and even visit past timelines. You also have a nice map with the location of all the characters so you tracking your moves is very simple. I love the watercolor artwork (especially the backgrounds). A small warning, a picture of my likeness is in the gallery; the developers had to work with what they had so I apologize to all of you for any ocular affront that may occur. Remember, Elsinore is not a happy place, my picture just adds to that. In a more serious statement, the music is wonderful. The dialogue is good but the voice work is not 100% but rather a summary of what is going on. It works here but I found it took a little bit to get used to it. Finally, LOTS of endings. This is a very rich game and once you figure out what is going on (that is, why you keep repeating the last few days), the game plan shifts and you have many interesting choices; for a small development team, you will be amazed at how rich this game is.

Major regrets? I wish I could have afforded more to this gem. I do hope the team keeps together and does another game; I'd back it in an instant! If you only enjoy this game 1/2 as much as I did, you will be very pleased!

review:
[h1] My favourite game of the year	[/h1]

A must for any Shakespeare nerd with lots of nods to other plays and little moments that made me grin, but you definitely don't need to have read Hamlet to play. 

The art is gorgeous, with fresh and inclusive character designs.  The game has intuitive, point and click gameplay with a focus on dialogue. The music is also fantastic and sets the mood perfectly!

It was incredibly fun to explore all of the possibilities- including all of the romance routes!

Elsinore  is a great extension of the Hamlet story and  provides a fleshed out, fully realised world where even characters like Bernardo have interesting arcs. 
This game is full of heart with emotional moments that suck you right in, as well as laugh out loud moments featuring Ophelia's sass. 

I would recommend playing the game in short bursts rather than sitting down for hours to play (even though I got so sucked into the story I ignored this advice) because the repetition can be frustrating at times. 

I absolutely recommend this game for anyone interested in Shakespeare, time travel or point and click adventure games.

review:
Just finished this today and all i can say is WOOOOOOOOW

Highly recommend this game- You play as Ophelia from Hamlet trying to, well, stop the events of Hamlet! You get stuck in a time loop, particularly one where you have an assassin after you. The characters and setting have set limitations, however, because of the depth of each character and every potential timeline route there is an intense richness to the game play. The graphics themselves are limited, but the writing is impeccable. Strong feminine narrative, strong narrative in general, strong main character and side characters! A lot of the game is experimentation and unexpected results. Death resulting from innocuous statements, etc, but this is all data to help you solve various puzzles you come across. 

Can be frustrating at times, as its sometimes unclear what to do to cause a certain time line, but that's part of the game itself, you need to experiment.

review:
I've been following the development of Elsinore excitedly since 2015. It looked like a game with everything I loved; Shakespeare, time-loops, difficult decisions, intriguing characters, branching storylines with a lot of replayability, the option to be extremely gay.... etc.

Now, after finally getting to play it, seven hours into the game, I can firmly say it was worth EVERY SINGLE MOMENT I waited for it. I'm not even a little bit done, haven't gotten a single non-death ending yet, but it has rocketed to favorite game status already. It blends in so well with the world Shakespeare created while adding incredible, logical takes on the characters, who are endearing and devastating and all hiding something. I want to unpeel it and get every single possible ending, discover EVERYTHING, which will probably take me a million years and I will gladly put the time in. It's gorgeously written and atmospheric, and I'm so excited to get answers to all the questions I have.

10/10, honestly.

review: The Elevator Pitch of "Groundhog Day, but in Hamlet, and you are Ophelia," intrigued me enough that I picked this game up shortly after reading about it. I'm glad I did. Re-living the tragedy from a character whose story was one of almost no agency, and giving that character the power to try again and again to avert tragedy, to save the members of the Danish court, is a lot of fun. It reminds me of one of my first-ever PC games (and a personal favorite,) The Colonel's Bequest, where eavesdropping on conversations by being at a certain place at a certain time reveals secrets about the cast of characters, and those secrets pull away layers of the greater mystery. Liberties have been taken with Shakespeare's tale (each change adds dimension to characters and the story, so purists can stuff it,) and the writing is uniformly personal and well-written, the branches the story take in each time loop as you share new information is dizzying, and I haven't found an illogical or broken path yet. I'm enjoying the journey through the four days of Shakespeare's tragedy, and have much more to discover. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046909876', 'num_games_owned': 648, 'num_reviews': 176, 'playtime_forever': 1744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1564796450}
review:
I backed this game on Kickstarter because the premise was really intriguing. I have not been at all disappointed. 

The team was extremely communicative throughout the production process, and the game has come a long way since the beta version that we got access to a while back. I have been so impressed with how much work (and communication) this team has put in through the development process. 

There is so much going on within the game during each time loop that one of the biggest challenges was figuring out how to catch people at certain points. The UI in the game does a really good job of helping track all of these.

UI pros: 
[list]
[*]Easily see the upcoming events in the timeline, as well as on the map (areas where events are about to take place are deep purple, then light purple while happening)
[*]Know where characters are at any time via the map (also see which events will involve which characters based on the timeline indicators)
[*]View current and past timeline choices
[*]Goals: View your list of objectives, and see which ones have been "stamped" as completed. Easily read your progress under the details of any goal
[*]Characters: Don't forget to read the bios from time to time. If you figure out a particular key element, it sometimes records the info here [spoiler] - for example, if you figure out the conditions to avoid Polonius' death, or how to keep Laertes in town[/spoiler]
[/list]

The only part of the UI I haven't found much use for is the hearsay section - as this mostly seems to be redundant of the goals. 

I love that the game is from Ophelia's perspective, and I love the game's take on the various characters (at the moment, Guildenstern is my favorite). I'm on about the 6th or so time loop, and enjoying the slow unraveling of the story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198199927275', 'num_games_owned': 343, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1547015941}
review:
Firstly, the developers of this game are incredibly sweet and allowed me early access to this game for academic purposes, so thank you so much again for that.

But the game itself - RPGs have the incredible opportunity, by virtue of the active engagement of the audience, to raise questions of how we speak about consequences of violence, given the media's relationship to counterfactualism. In more static media, readers or listeners can ask about counterfactual possibilities - how might a change in plot have impacted the narrative? What if Ophelia refused to spy for Claudius and Polonius? But only in an RPG like Elsinore can you actually explore all the various consequences of these counterfactual possibilities, because you're constantly looping through them, so you can test and retest theories and explore multiple avenues of consequence with a player character who is just as aware of these consequences as the player, because Ophelia remembers. Just go up to Claudius and tell him you know he killed Old King Hamlet? Sure! See what happens if you tell Gertrude about her husband's ghost wandering around the battlements that you saw the other night? It's an option! 

Rewriting a game like this and centering it on Ophelia reinterprets the story as her struggle for agency in a world that ultimately seeks to limit it. It allows the player to explore a "Hamlet" in light of what Ophelia's increased agency would hold for the development of the story's plot, and that to me is what honestly makes this game so powerful, because it's not just "Hamlet but Groundhog Day" - it's "if we gave Ophelia just a little more capacity to act in Elsinore, what might happen?"

What if she was suspicious of Claudius and decided to investigate? 

And it's very telling that, without spoilers, that the first loop the player must complete is finding some means (there were multiple, last I checked) to keep Polonius alive.

If you like Hamlet, but you love Ophelia, and you wish directors gave her a little more agency than hysteria, and you absolutely love decision-based RPGs (I'm a big Dishonored fan) where cumulative decisions matter, this is a fantastic game for you, I cannot recommend it highly enough. The art design is beautiful, it's fun, and the team did a phenomenal job.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005672212', 'num_games_owned': 387, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 851, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 389, 'last_played': 1569236059}
review:
Elsinore ist ein Spiel, welches dem Spieler eine Geschichte erleben lässt. Der Spieler kann sich dabei frei durch grafisch einfache, aber durchaus schön gemalte, Welt bewegen, mit Charakteren über ausgewählte Themen (Dialogoptionen) sprechen und gelegentlich weitere Entscheidungen treffen. Die Spielwelt ist so gestaltet, das an mehreren Orten etwas zur gleichen Zeit passiert, so dass der Spieler die Geschichte mehrmals spielen kann und neue Inhalte vorfindet. Wissen aus alten Zeitschleifen kann in neue mitgenommen werden, so das diese Geschichtsabschnitte auch nicht wiederholt gespielt werden müssen. Es gibt verschiedene Geschichtenstränge denen der Spieler nachgehen kann. Die Geschichte des Spieles ist sehr verzweigt: so bietet z.B. ein Schauspieler an verschiedene Aufführungen an und je nachdem welche der Spieler wählt, trifft diese Aufführung auf eine andere Resonanz bei den Zuschauern und die Geschichte nimmt einen völlig anderen Lauf. So eine Aufführung kann z.B. einem Mörder spiegeln, das andere von seinem Mord wissen. Der Inhalt ist relativ umfangreich, Wiederholungen lassen sich im Grunde genommen durch die Zeitvorspulfunktion übergehen und das Spiel bleibt auch nach vielen Wiederholungen in der Zeitschleife (Ich bin jetzt ungefähr bei 20) interessant.
Fazit: Elsinore ist ein gutes Spiel, welches eine ungewöhnliche Geschichte bietet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066058799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 746, 'last_played': 1563664333}
review:
This is a really interesting and entertaining game that was even wilder and more thought-provoking than I thought it'd be. If you're interested by "time-looping Hamlet", or exploring interactive narratives, or you love messy melodrama, then I really recommend playing this game.

High points: 
- There is SO much that can happen in this game. One of my plans was totally foiled because one character, who I was trying to have murdered, ended up killing themselves, and then the OTHER character who was meant to get murdered ended up seducing me, and I thought "sure why not" and it went totally off the rails from there.
- Ophelia is a fantastic protagonist
- The difficulty is tuned well which can be really hard to get right in these kinds of games. I was often tempted to use a walkthrough, but never had to
- Many cats and dogs that you can pet
- The music is great
- The overarching story is very fun and has plenty of twists
- The supporting characters are really nicely developed. It's impressive how much they manage to get out of a few conversations. I ended up loving them all, even though you can see how their flaws line up in a way that leads to tragedy
- It actually made me like Hamlet (the character) even though I really hated him after seeing the play

This game also has a very interesting spin on the time loop mechanic and the 'accretive player character' format. It's an incredibly interesting way to adapt a work of fiction, particularly a tragedy, particularly a story that's had so many iterations already with different things happening every time over hundreds of years. 

This game is lacking polish in some parts - you will have to get used to Ophelia 'hiding' in completely plain sight, and sometimes dialogue is inconsistent with previous events. The way characters dash from place to place is a little unnatural, but it does feel like a play, too.

I'd recommend this game to fans of visual novels or interactive fiction, like Long Live the Queen or the Zero Escape games. This review ended up being way too long, but in short, BUY THIS GAME!

Note: this review is of an early access version of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004575166', 'num_games_owned': 698, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1458, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1458, 'last_played': 1563312926}
review:
I backed the game and I'm not disappointed at all. It's very narrative-rich, complex and mastered. There's always something new to discover, so the sense of repetitiveness is not really felt before near the end of the game.
You don't need to know Hamlet's story already as the game deals accurately to not lose the player. There's enough options of ergonomy. It's still a rather difficult game, but in a good sense in my opinion.
You'll need 20 to 30 hours to complete it. It's really not a small game, there's a huge sum of work within it. Know that there are 11 endings to unlock plus one or two "true" endings after that; don't reach for a "perfect" end that you cannot attain before you have access to the conclusion.

On the minus side: the side stories added to the original piece may or may not please you, but can you harsh a writer for not writing as well as William Shakespeare ? I find some of them were great.
And the game I played, before the public release, had numerous bugs, including some that requested relaunching the game. But they were patched one after the other.

I highly recommend this game.
